content:
Diagnosis:		Locally advanced squamous cell carcinoma left upper lobe lung

Staging:		T4N2M0 (incomplete mediastinal staging), PD-L1 45%

Treatment:		Cycle 1-2 Carboplatin/Paclitaxel/Pembrolizumab Mar-Apr 2024
		Radical radiotherapy 60Gy/30# commenced 15 Apr 2024, discontinued after 12#

Current Status:	Disease progression with new malignant pleural effusion

[redacted name] has unfortunately developed increasing breathlessness over the past 10 days, requiring emergency admission on 2/5/24. CT shows new left pleural effusion with collapse of left lower lobe and progression of primary mass from 6.2cm to 8.4cm. Performance status has declined to ECOG 3. Pleural fluid cytology confirms malignant cells.?

Chemotherapy has been discontinued due to clinical deterioration. Chest drain inserted with 1.2L fluid drained, providing temporary symptom relief. However, rapid re-accumulation noted.?

I have discussed the situation with [redacted name] and family today. Given poor performance status and disease progression on first-line treatment, focus will shift to symptom control. Referral made to palliative care team for pleural management and symptom support. Outpatient review arranged in 2 weeks, sooner if needed.? Blood results show new acute kidney injury with creatinine 156, likely pre-renal. Community palliative care referral completed today.

cancer_timeline.value: Radiotherapy discontinued after 12 fractions due to clinical deterioration
CT shows new left pleural effusion with collapse of left lower lobe, primary mass increased from 6.2cm to 8.4cm
Pleural fluid cytology positive for malignant cells
Chemotherapy discontinued due to clinical deterioration
Emergency admission due to increasing breathlessness

patient_facts.value: Increasing breathlessness with rapid re-accumulation of pleural effusion
New acute kidney injury with creatinine 156

status_updates.value: Locally advanced lung cancer with disease progression on first-line treatment. New malignant pleural effusion and clinical deterioration requiring transition to palliative care.
Disease progression with increase in primary mass and new malignant pleural effusion
Discontinued chemotherapy and radiotherapy due to disease progression and clinical deterioration
Deterioration to ECOG PS 3 with increasing breathlessness
Outpatient review in 2 weeks, referral to palliative care team and community palliative care
